results.title: The Last time I saw Paris
results.creator_credit: Richard Brooks, Jack Cummings and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Charles Wills (Van Johnson) is a GI with literary ambitions who goes to Paris and meets and falls in love with the wealthy Helen Ellswirth (Elizabeth Taylor). Charles’ ambition to write a novel falls to pieces as failure to sell his writing causes him to turn to alcohol. During a drunken argument Johnson accidentally locks Helen out of their Parisian apartment, causing her to catch a fatal dose of pneumonia. When Helen dies, custody of their child is granted to Helen’s sister, who always disapproved of her sister’s abusive partner. Shocked into action, Charles returns home and finally finds success as a writer, and the conviction to try and regain custody of his daughter. Based on the tragic love story by F. Scott Fitzgerald. Cast also includes Donna Reed, Walter Pidgeon and Eva Gabor.

results.title: Nothing sacred
results.creator_credit: William Wellman, David O. Selznick and Selznick International Pictures
results.brief_description: Carol Lombard is hilariously funny playing the role of Hazel Flagg in this outstanding black comedy. Hazel’s bumbling doctor mistakenly diagnoses her as having fatal radium poisoning. Although she’s never felt better, Hazel pretends to be dying in order to accept the offer of an all-expenses-paid visit to New York City made by a newspaper reporter. By the time the reporter begins churning out daily reports of the tragedy, half of Manhattan is in tears and Hazel is built up to be a brave ‘suffering in silence’ charmer and is lionized by the media and public. When Hazel cannot disguise her good health any longer, a group of her financial backers wise up to her ruse and ask her to find a way to die and save them all further embarassment.This was one of the first screwball comedies ever produced, and possibly one of the finest.

results.title: L.I.E. = LIE [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Michael Cuesta, Rene Bastian, Linda Moran, Belladonna and Alter Ego
results.brief_description: Writer/director Michael Cuesta’s feature film debut deals with the difficult, often emotive, subject of paedophilia with compassion and sensitivity combined with an air of realism and awareness of teenage sexuality and the complexities of life that often face young male adolescents as they forge their way into adulthood. L.I.E., which stands for Long Island Expressway, is a symbolic reminder to 15 year-old Howie (Paul Franklin Dano) who has recently lost his mother through a car accident on the L.I.E. and is struggling to cope emotionally with her loss. His father Marty (Bruce Altman) who finds solace in a shallow based-on-sex relationship with his new girlfriend is also on the run from the law through his corrupt business practices and barely has time for his lonely grieving son. Disillusioned and confused, Howie forms a bond with three rather rebellious and streetwise dysfunctionals who spend more time out of school than in, robbing local houses to finance their habits. The relationship between Howie, and Gary (Billy Kay), who unbeknownst to Howie sometimes works as a male prostitute, evolves into something beyond friendship, causing Howie to reflect on his sexuality and his feelings towards Gary. But the issue of Howie’s sexuality soon takes another path when through one of his robbery escapades with Gary, he meets middle-aged ex-marine “Big John” Harrigan (Brian Cox) - a regular customer of Gary’s who has a penchant for boys in their early teens. When Gary runs off to California, and his father is arrested by the FBI, Howie finds an unexpected degree of emotional support in his relationship with the rather curious and compassionate paedophile who seemingly understands Howie’s tenuous and helpless situation. A very moving story with moments of warmth and humour but which also delves into the murkier side of urban life and paedophilia. In the director’s words “It was vital the audience could relate to Big John, even sympathise with him, but I tried very hard to make sure his intentions were constantly blurred”. Superb cinemaphotography by Romeo Tirone and outstanding performances by the lead actors, makes this multi-award winning film compelling viewing, both emotionally and psychologically. (Awards: Edinburgh 2001, Stockholm 2001, Independent Spirit Awards 2002) [End of file]

results.title: Viva Zapata! [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Elia Kazan, Darryl F. Zanuck and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: This dramatisation of the role of the peasant leader Emilio Zapata in the Mexican Revolution was the product of a close collaboration between screenwriter John Steinbeck and director Elia Kazan. Zapata (played by Marlon Brando), an ambiguous historical figure, is idealised in the film yet a certain psychological complexity is maintained. He is a symbolic figure, a ‘natural’ leader who is attuned to the essential needs of the people. Revolution thus becomes a natural rather than a revolutionary process. The weak idealist, Madero, cannot make the revolution work. The shadowy figure of Fernando, the advisor, stands as a symbol for Stalinism. Cast also includes Jean Peters, Anthony Quinn, Joseph Wiseman and Arnold Moss.

results.title: I'll get you for this = Lucky Nick Cain
results.creator_credit: Joseph M. Newman, Joseph Kaufman, Romulus Films and Kaydor Productions
results.brief_description: Based on James Hadley Chase’s novel of the same name, this crime thriller tells the story of Nick Cain (George Raft), American gambler visiting the Mediterranean town of San Paola where he befriends a young orphan shoe-shine boy named Toni (Enzo Staiola). Nick soon finds his way to the casino where all is not quite as it appears and trouble it seems has a way of finding him. Enter the lovely Kay Wonderly (Coleen Gray) a tourist who becomes a victim to the Casino, losing all her money and at the mercy of the Casino managers. Fate takes a hand and before long Nick and Kay find themselves not only sharing a mutual attraction but also of having been framed for murdering a US Treasury Agent. Hiding Kay away in a small village, Nick sets about doing a bit of his own detective work to find out just who the real murderers are. A film classic of drama and intrigue. Cast also includes Charles Goldner, Walter Rilia, Greta Grynt. Features an introduction and conclusion summary by Bill Collins.

results.title: I'm going home = Je rentre a la maison [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Manuel de Oliveira, Paolo Branco, Madragoa Filmes, Gemini Films, France 2 Cinema and Artificial Eye
results.brief_description: In this elegiac feature from Portuguese director Manoel de Oliveira, Michel Piccoli plays Gilbert Valence, a well-respected, and aging, theatre and screen actor. Valence is aggrieved by the sudden death of close family, retreating somewhat, but also drawing enormous pleasure from the responsibility of caring for his grandson. Internalising his grief, Valence comes to terms with the fact that society is changing whilst he remains the same - his agent offers him parts in lucrative but lowbrow dramas, despite Valence’s protestation that he values his craft; similarly Valence is outraged by the suggestion that he may find solace in romance with a young actress. Piccoli puts in a grand performance as Valence, and de Oliveira captures the savouring of everyday pleasures - a fine new pair of shoes or a daily coffee at his favourite cafe. These observations set a gently comic, if slightly melancholic tone, providing a deft and moving rumination on the themes of aging and artistry. Support cast include Catherine Deneuve, as a fellow thespian and John Malkovich, as an American director. This film represented a breakthrough for de Oliveira, who started his career as a silent era - reflected in the use of expression and gesture to convey meaning, rather than dialogue laden exchanges.

results.title: Suzhou River = Su Zhou He [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Lou Ye, Philippe Bober, Nai An, Essential Film and Dream Factory
results.brief_description: The Suzhou River is the backdrop to this haunting tale of obsessive love and mystery set in the not so illustrious part of modern day Shanghai. Told through the eyes and words of a freelance videographer, we follow Mardar (Jia Hongsheng) a motor-cycle courier in his mid-twenties who does his pick-ups and deliveries, no questions asked. However, when Mardar finds himself delivering Moudan (Zhou Xun), the 16 year-old daughter of an alcoholic smuggler, to her aunt, he has no idea what is in store for him. A tender loving relationship soon forms between the two only to be put to the test when Mardar is persuaded by his shady associates to kidnap Moudan and hold her to ransom. Moudan, heartbroken and betrayed, makes her escape vowing to Mardar before jumping off the bridge into the murky depths of the Suzhou River, that she will come back as a mermaid to haunt him. Accused of Moudan’s murder, Mardar spends a few years in prison until his release, when grief-stricken and distraught, he sets out to find his beloved Moudan. When he encounters Meimei (Zhou Xun), a nightclub dancer who performs in an aquarium as a mermaid and who bears a striking resemblance to Moudan, Mardar becomes totally obsessed in the belief that Meimei is his lost love, Moudan. Intricate, mesmerising and visually stunning, Lou Ye pays homage to Hitchcock’s “Vertigo” and Wong Kar Wai’s “Chungking Express” in his treatment of this compelling multi award-winning film. Cinematography by Wang Yu and original music by Jorg Lemberg. (Awards: Paris; Fantasporto; Rotterdam; Viennale)

results.title: Kirikou and the sorceress [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Michel Ocelot, Jacques Vercruyssen, Paul Thiltges, Didier Brunner, France 3 Cinema, Monipoly Productions, Odec Kid Cartoons and Les Armateurs
results.brief_description: A delightful animated fable, “Kirikou and the sorceress” starts with a child, Kirikou, speaking to his mother from the womb. Once born, Kirikou seeks about healing his village - principally from the curse that an ill-tempered sorceress has placed on the village including drying up the wells and eating up the men-folk. In his bid to confront the sorceress and see the end to his tribe’s woes, Kirikou undertakes a perilous journey meeting an array of colourful beings and jungle creatures. The charm of the narrative is that it presents from a child’s perspective with uncomplicated views on life, unsullied by conjecture and misguided beliefs. The African village where this whimsical tale is set is abundant with colour, humour, culture and magic, with animation inspired by the earth colours and myths of Africa and imbued with a rich palette reminiscent of 19th century French painter Henri Rousseau. Music scored by Senegalese musician Youssou N’dour.

Music scored by Senegalese musician Youssou N’dour.
description_for_label: A delightful animated fable, “Kirikou and the sorceress” starts with a child, Kirikou, speaking to his mother from the womb. Once born, Kirikou seeks about healing his village - principally from the curse that an ill-tempered sorceress has placed on the village including drying up the wells and eating up the men-folk. In his bid to confront the sorceress and see the end to his tribe’s woes, Kirikou undertakes a perilous journey meeting an array of colourful beings and jungle creatures. The charm of the narrative is that it presents from a child’s perspective with uncomplicated views on life, unsullied by conjecture and misguided beliefs. The African village where this whimsical tale is set is abundant with colour, humour, culture and magic, with animation inspired by the earth colours and myths of Africa and imbued with a rich palette reminiscent of 19th century French painter Henri Rousseau. Music scored by Senegalese musician Youssou N’dour.

results.title: Alphaville
results.creator_credit: Jean-Luc Godard, Andre Michelin, Pathe Films and Athos Film
results.brief_description: A secret agent, posing as a journalist, from the ‘the world without’, penetrates ‘the world within’ - Alphaville. In his version of a futuristic dystopia, Jean-Luc Godard embraces a tech-noir aesthetic where human beings have become robotic slaves to technology, deprived of individuality and independent thought. In “Alphaville” the hero, played by Eddie Constantine with an embittered edge, evoking the ghost of Philipe Marlowe, has a mission to eliminate an eminent professor, the inventor of Alpha 60, a superior computer that governs society. The professor’s daughter, Natasha, played with an alluringly demure sensuality by Anna Karina, is the detective’s guide and also his love interest as he negotiates the bizarre, totalitarian state. Godard’s narrative is littered with numerous references, in particular, Aldous Huxley’s “Brave New World” and George Orwell’s “1984”. Godard uses the modernist 1960 Paris aesthetic to great effect, succeeding in presenting the city as a glimmering, ominous prison, where absurd and inhumane policies intermingle. Several memorable sequences include a firing squad - a cultural performance, accompanied by elegant water ballet sequences - that is witnessed by an admiring audience. An unusual addition to the canon of French New Wave cinema. Glorious black and white cinematography by Raoul Coutard. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Dead or alive 2: Birds [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Takashi Miike, Makoto Okada, Yoshihiro Masuda, Excellent Film, Toei Video and Daiei Motion Picture Company
results.brief_description: This film is an unusual sequel to “Dead or Alive”; unusual in that is has the same two lead actors but virtually nothing else in common with the original in terms of plot. In this instalment (one of three) Sho Aikawa plays Mizuki Okamoto, a hit man hired to execute a member of the Yakuza. But instead the opportunity is missed when a mysterious man beats him to it. Fearing retribution Okamoto flees to the small island of his youth, only to be met by the same assassin whom he discovers is an old friend. Together, the two of them join forces using the proceeds from hits to buy vaccines for Third World children. Despite this set-up, Miike has very little use for the conventions of narrative, preferring to engage in the violent, kinetic excesses that are his signature, not to mention the dabbling in surrealist motifs, flashbacks and asides that often baffle. An intriguing mix of humour and action with redemptive overtones. Cast includes Show Aikawa, Riki Takeuchi, Endo Kenichi, Shinya Tsukamoto and Edison Chen.
